This game is fantastic.  Mechanically, it's a side scrolling beat 'em up that strips out all the unnecessary complex inputs.  Instead, you're focused on combos, where you're reacting in real-time to where you've knocked the enemies.  It's really satisfying to put a nice combo together.

The art for this game is hilarious - anyone I've played with has been in stiches.  The characters all actually play in fairly different ways when you get into it.

While everyone has been nostalgic for old beat 'em ups like X-Men or Ninja Turtles, this just shows how much better games have gotten in the past few decades.  Certainly pick this up for a good co-op/party game experience.

34705376.review: Streets of Fury EX is a game that harkens back to the simpler days of beat em ups with a few modern twists. They used real people to portray the characters in the story,Digitized graphics is something I miss in gaming,so that's a treat. Most of the designs of these characters are stupid and plain but the cheesyness of it brings the games charm in the looks deparment which is for the most part good and looks the part of a beat em up. However the game does faulter in the Game play. Enemies who have weapons will rush in and attack giving you NO able way of blocking or parrying (To parry most attacks in the game you have to have the reflexes of a god). Blocking is almost useless because groups of enemies will attack relentlessly until you are able to pull off a counter by which you take tons of damage before hand... I feel the game play needs tweaking because there is actually a fun experience to be had here given the issues. 4 player action, catchy sound track and some characters acting live version of Capcom and SNK characters! There is even a level up system where you gain more playable characters and there are a bunch of them. I love that idea!  The only reason I recommend it is the cheese has to be seen to believe and it's a fun little 35 min diversion (granted you don't lose all your continues by the end),but don't spend more than $5 on Streets of Fury EX. Let's hope if there is a sequel we can see some redefine game play tweaks and maybe more vareity in enemies.

[h1]Divertidisimo![/h1]

un juego al viejo estilo Beat'em up de peleas callejeras, como los clasicos streets of rage o double dragon.
en este caso mo sorprendio gratamente el sistema de combate que tiene, bastante profundo, versatil y variado. pense que iba a tener 2 botones para pegar y uno para saltar como los clasicos de siempre, pero no. ademas del genial sistema de furia, parrys, bloqueos, cada uno de los 3 botones de ataque cambia si le sumamos presionar hacia adelante, arriba o abajo, aumentando asi las posibilidades de combos variados y mayor profundidad en el combate.

lo unico negativo que le veo es que puede ser un poco corto, aunque depende cuanto lo disfrutes. el juego ademas cuenta con desbloqueables que de verdad le agregan interes y te invitan a rejugarlo. pero si te planteas terminar la "campaña" 1 ves y ya, entonces en 40-45min ya esta. y lo que mas lamento es que no tenga coop/multiplayer online. se puede jugar hasta 4 jugadores en local, de hecho, lo he aprovechado cuando tuve oportunidad y pasamos un buen momento entre amigos. pero realmente me gustaria poder jugarlo con amigos online.

en resumen, segun mi expereriencia personal:

Lo bueno:
 
- estilo interesante, fotorealista al estilo de los primeros mortal kombat.
- muchos personajes diferentes y varios desbloqueables.
- buen humor, desde los sonidos o movimientos que hacen algunos al atacar, hasta escenas y animaciones que se iran viendo durante el juego.
- sistema bastante profundo, pero facil de aprender y divertido.

Lo malo:

- No tiene Multiplayer online
- para algunos puede resultar corto

33065207.review: Streets of Fury is a decent beat-em-up, the digitized sprites give the game a lot of goofy charm and the fighting game style combat is fun. The biggest problem with the game though is unlike a lot of old beatemups there is no desperation move that gets enemies off of you. So this game just loves having a bunch of enemies getting you into ridiculously long combo strings that you have very little option to get out of. There are tech rolls and counters but they take long to build so you just watch your health melt away. Enemies just love dropping down from the top of the stage and cheap shotting you, a sin many old beatemups never had. You have to play way too defensively and they don't do it in a fun way like Double Dragon Neon where you had the Shine dodge roll system. It's worth a couple of bucks and is a fun for a while, but its utter punishment of any real offensive play drags it down.

31090044.review:
** Pure Unbridled Fun **

Old digitized actor fighting games tended to have a lot of things in common - they looked ridiculous, were expensive to make & play, and weren't very fun.

Streets of Fury EX is what you get if you only left in the ridiculous, focused on fun, and actually made a good game.

Pick from a large cast of people, many obviously average individuals hamming it up on camera, hit the streets and beat the crap out of a huge number of people in the most over-the-top ways possible, all while maintaining a fun, free-style combo system that's surprisingly deep and satisfying.

Reminding me a lot of Guardian Heroes with it's three-lane combat and the ability to continue to juggle the limp bodies of your defeated enemies until they explode (yup) this is a cooperative brawling game with the options that should make anyone who loves fun happy.

Want to learn a character or blow off steam?  Set it to Easy and enjoy 99 continues.  If you every want to enable friendly fire, this is the mode to do it in.

Want more of a challenge?  Set it Normal; you'll need a basic understanding of the core mechanics to survive.

Know the game really well?  Set it to hard -- only people with solid knowledge of the game's mechanics can complete the campaigns.

The range of characters go from a Streetfighter/Art of Fighting type, to a dry-humping Frenchman with dreadlocks that hurls a barrage of VHS tapes but they've all got different styles, strengths and the ability to string together fantastic combos.

Don't let the silliness fool you; the game's mechanics are surprisingly deep with a super meter (for Fury attacks), Guard meters (broken through repeated hits), parries (which stun enemies when times right), and Stamina (used for Special attacks) plus a less-broken Combo Breaker counter if you're hit too many times.

Each character has 3 basic attack buttons (normal, launcher, special) and each button provides a string of 4 different attack patterns, each with different uses.  

Game play is centered around stringing together combos and juggling enemies so you don't get overwhelmed, using normal attacks to give your Stamina time to recharge and then launching into Furries for limited invulnerability.  Each type of enemy (except bosses) have a limited moveset but special properties, and stages are well designed, switching up the action from simple beat-downs on a large mob to dealing with smaller numbers of special-property enemies that require utilizing the mechanics taught earlier to deal with.  (Example:  Super-armour enemies with a very slow guard-breaking attack that need hit-and-run tactics, or aggressive enemies that are better dealt with via parry)  The game also rewards bold tactics, such as using the Parry to thwart a small area-afffect guard-breaking blast.

Throw in Survival, Challenges (which really test how well you've learned mechanics) and you have a very solid fighter that other more serious fighters wish they were.

28792103.review:
There is certainly fun to be had here for lovers of the Beat 'em Up genre. It's not to be taken too seriously and it's "cheap production value" and classic Mortal Kombat-esque sprites is part of the charm. The game play shows similarities to Phantom Breaker: Battle Ground (input a command to switch planes) and various fighting games in terms of combat. There are tons of playable characters, including the Nostalgia Critic and Benzaie from ThatGuyWithTheGlasses.com that are unlocked as you perform combos to increase your Security Level. 

Combat wise, you have a variety of "Mash X" string combos that change based on the direction you are holding. The Y button provides various launchers that also function based on the direction you're holding. The B button actions like the Smash Bros games as well, providing different special moves like travel attacks, slide kicks and dragon punches. The game doesn't tell you this, but doing the down B attack (or the B attack) in the air can sometimes do a sort of dive kick, which can be handy in dealing damage and continuing combos. Finally, there are "fury" moves which act like supers from a fighting game. Both you and enemies can block and be guard crushed, and after being attacked too much, either of you can perform an unblockable counter (even as you're dying!), though, enemies don't do it too often. 

You can string these moves together, in silly, spammy, but bombastic combos. However, some enemies can resist being stunlocked/interuppted and perform a powerful attack that will set you up to take more damage or be juggled. I can't quite always say the game is fair. One the one hand, you can batter the enemies in an almost Dynasty Warriors style fashion, and it takes learning of the enemy behaviors to really maximize your dominance. On the other hand, you can easily get stun locked and juggled to oblivion, especially by some of the more annoying enemies like the "Drop kicking cornrow F**ker" or "nunchuck slinging b**ches". There are many places I dread in the first act (which I can't beat the last boss on :( ) because I'm expecting to loose 3/4th of my health to a handful of enemies.  (though, some playable characters might handle them better than others, you have to unlock them though).


These unfair moments hold me from seriously suggesthing this game. I had fun with it, and not a terrible buy at sale, but I don't recommend it if you're looking for a good brawler that you want to finish. Maybe get it on sale to experience for an hour or so, or spend hours getting good at it, which seems preposterous for it's corny nature.

28175626.review: Streets of Fury pays homage to every Capcom arcade beat-em-up I loved when I was a teenager, and even utilizes a combat system very similar to Marvel vs. Capcom and Night Stalkers.  The main issue I am having with the game is the laziness of the overall character design and aesthetic.  After a while (3 hours in my case), the game starts to feel monotonous since I don't really care about what is happening.  Castle Crashers is a similar game that keeps you wanting to progress further despite the obvious grind of beating up bad guys again and again.  The difference is the world that Behemoth built that is very engaging and detailed, while Streets of Fury feels like a demo that someone more inspired should reskin.

27337347.review:
This is the most fun I've ever had with a beat 'em up.

Streets of Fury EX certainly doesn't have the ambiance of Dungeons & Dragons: Chronicles of Mystara, or the soundtrack of Streets of Rage, or the visuals of Capcom's Alien vs Predator.
But what the game lacks in artistic and techincal prowess, it makes up for with its zany humour, large cast of playable characters, and awesome gameplay depth.
Each character feels very unique, and though a few can feel underpowered, they're still interesting in their own right. The combo system is super flexible - way more than I ever expected! Chain combos, special moves, dash and jump cancels, juggles, OTGs, and the coming update even adds parries to the mix. Hell we're still finding new ways to do amazing, super damaging combos!

Worth mentioning as well, a few internet and fighting game community figures are playable characters! Most of them are popular in France (this is a French game after all), like Mr Quaraté, Yamato and Bob Lennon, but you'll probably recognize Benzaie from the That Guy With The Glasses website. Well, the next update adds Kayane and Ryan Hart as playable characters as well! And we're hearing rumours that Doug Walker himself might be in the update after that…

This game is Heaven for completionists who want to get top marks on every mode, and want to master every character. There is a beefy challenge mode that will really test your skills, and higher difficulties for the main campaigns really bring on the pain. The one problem is the absence of online mode, but the campaign's second story will help scratch that multiplayer itch if you can't do local co-op (or local versus!).

And, hey, it DOES have an awesome soundtrack as well!

Es ist ein Klassisches beat’em up man Läuft von Links nach Rechts und haut alles um was sich bewegt. Die Grafik hat ihren eigenen scharm und passt auch in die ganze inszenierung des Spiels. Das Kampfsystem der einzelnen spielbaren Figuren ist im Großen und ganzen ausgewogen. Wobei man oft auch einfach nur Butten Mashing betreibt. Aber die ganzen Spezial Attacken sind einfach zu schön und immer wieder unterhaltsam. Der Sound Track des Spieles ist das beste am gesamten Game.

26881926.review:
A friend of mine and I tripped across this while looking for hilariously bad games on XBox Indies.  We started off laughing our asses off at the character sprites that looked like they were made by a few friends getting together on a Saturday with a camera or reading the bizarre character bios and backstories.  But then we found ourselves genuinely hooked on the combo happy multiplayer.  After finishing the demo we actually ponied up for the full version and played it all weekend.

Fast forward to 2016 when I noticed Streets of Fury EX randomly on Steam.  I wasted no time picking it up (and immediately  notifying my friend from before).  This "EX" version is largely the same as the XBox version, but it adds more content and higher resolution assets.

The game itself is a beat em up that takes a lot of queues from Guardian Heroes on the Sega Saturn.  You and your opponents shift between three vertical planes.  You'll be tasked with punching out scores of bad guys using one of a roster of characters that all look pretty much like normal people in their street clothes.  But just like Guardian Heroes you can easily pull off ridiculous combos by stringing together elaborate-but-easy-to-pull-off moves.  Lots of launching, air combos, juggling, and crowd controlling AOEs.  Inputs are simple and once you have the basics down you can be racking up combos in the hundreds in no time.  With up to 4 players going at it at the same time, things can get absolutely bananas.

So the gameplay is fun (though not necessarily perfectly balanced) but the presentation is definitely what got its hooks in me.  It's all very low budget and none of the "actors" look particularly menacing.  Bosses are usually just regular mobs that are scaled bigger or tinted a different color.  This may all sound unimpressive but it adds to the game's charm: it's clearly a low budget effort from a small team, but the game emulates the fun of Guardian Heroes exceptionally well.  The game can eventually get repetitive with a limited number of backgrounds and characters, but I say for those that know what they're getting into it's a hugely fun time.

Not only am I loving the weird look that makes me feel like I'm playing a Midway game from way back when, but these controls are tight!

All this is wrapped up in a sense of humour that had me chuckling from time to time, and I had to hold it in cuz I'm at work.

24151198.review:
This was a pleasant surprise in every sense of the word.

When you look at this, you probably want to laugh at how ridiculous this looks, yet how intriguing at its game play. In fact, I only bought this game because a friend of mine showed it to me one day. When he got me and a couple other friends together for a game, I was left impressed and amused. Naturally, I got curious enough to want to get the game now.

What can be said about this? Well you really cannot do any worse for $10. For $10, you get two campaign modes, five levels each, a good cast of playable characters with their own combo strings to discover, four player cooperative and competitive play, a few other games modes thrown in for good measure, you get enough to justify the price, yet it feels like a huge treat to me.

Maybe I'm being too favorable to it, so let me make it simple:
-Do you enjoy beat em ups?
-Do you enjoy fighting games?
-Do you still find digitized sprites to be charming?
-Do you plan on getting some friends together for some games?
-Do you enjoy something that's simple to figure out yet complex to master?
-Do you grow tired of beat em ups with RPG stats like I have?

You will find enjoyment in this game. I never regretted it, and there is a good chance that neither will you.

23937547.review:
Llevaba tiempo buscando un juego al estilo Street of Rage, saga que me encanta aun hoy jugar con mi novia, sea emulador o el remake hecho por fans. Buscaba algo parecido desde hacía tiempo por steam, el típico juego de ir dando mamporros a todo lo que se mueva para jugar en cooperativo, pero por desgracia soy un desconocedor de este género y la mayoría de juegos que encontraba eran de disparos estilo Metal Slug o Contra y eso ya no me gusta, hasta que di con Streets of Fury EX.

No se bien como analizar este juego, es un claro homenaje a Street of Rage y otros juegos de este estilo, quizá en un primero momento me chocó la estética de sus personajes (si, se hace muy extraño ver esas capturas de personas reales con fondos fotografiados y mezclados con gráficos simplones hechos por ordenador). Pero al final me decidí a comprarlo y no me arrepiento. La de risas que me estoy echando jugando en cooperativo, a parte de que disfruto del juego cada partida que juego. Ahora pasaré a comentar brevemente aquello que me parece reseñable del juego.

- La jugabilidad, pese a que el juego es el típico avanzar y aporrear a todos los enemigos nos encontramos con un muy buen sistema de combos, ademas de que cada personaje posee 3 tipos diferences de especiales que podemos ejecutar una vez llenamos nuestro medidor de "Fury". Un tutorial nos explica al principio el funcionamiento en profundidad del sistema de combate pero tendremos que dedicarle buenas horas a saber cuando protegernos, esquivar, atacar a ciertos enemigos, etc...

- La dificultad sin duda es elevada en los modos de juego Hard y en adelante, apenas he podido completarlo en cooperativo en Medium (aún no se jugarlo bien evidentemente), pero sin duda ofrece buenos ratos y un desafio para aquellos que les gusta rejugarlo en dificultades mayores. Ademas de que segun derrotemos enemigos y hagamos combos mas largos subiremos el "Security Level" con el cual podemos desbloquear el resto de personajes (son 15 en total) y otros modos de juego (otro modo historia, modo versus, survival, etc...).


No puedo decir nada malo pues era lo que quería y esperaba, es divertido, gracioso, extraño y alocado por momentos. Un indie que me ofrece aquello que buscaba, quizá eche en falta el poder coger armas (bates, tuberias, cuchillos, etc...) algo típico en muchos juegos de este género, pero ofrece un buen sistema de combate y combos en compensacion.

Sin duda lo recomiendo para aquellos que vayan a jugarlo acompañados, ya que solo se puede hacer algo pesado. La pena es que no tenga logros o cromos, un gran punto a favor para cumplir ciertos retos, rejugarlo mas, etc...

22609014.review:
[h1]Streets of Fury EX[/h1]

Streets of Fury EX ist ein lustiges Spiel in dem es darum geht andere zu verprügeln. Es gibt auch eine Story in der es auch darum geht sich mit anderen zu Prügeln.

[h1]Inhalt[/h1]

[b]Story[/b]

Paris ist gefallen,
Straßenbanden haben die Kontrolle übernommen.
Die Armee ist machtlos gegen die gehärtete Kriminalität.
Sie und Ihre Bande sind eingestellt worden,
direkt von den Straßen von LA,
durch die verängstigte französische Regierung.
Ihre Mission ist es, die Banden zu vernichten und die
frühere Sicherheit wiederherzustellen und die macht dem Präsidenten zurückzugeben.
Die nationale Einheit stützt sich auf deine Fäuste.
Es ist Zeit, Feuer mit Feuer zu bekämpfen.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

Bevor du anfängst zu Kämpfen kannst du dir einen Kämpfer auswählen, am Anfang hast du nur fünf Kämpfer aber du schaltest immer mehr Kämpfer im Laufe des Spiels frei.
Im Kampf kommen eigentlich immer die gleichen Gegner, nur wenn du den Boss besiegst kommen neue dazu.
Es gibt drei verschiedene Modi auf denen du Spielen kannst, zuerst kommt der Kampagne Modus in dem du die Story durch spielst, dann kommt der challenge Modus den du erst mit Level 5 freischaltest in dem geht es darum verschiedene aufgaben zu erledigen, danach kommt der Survival Modus den du erst mit Level 18 freischaltest in dem geht es darum so lange zu Kämpfen bis du Stirbst.

[h1]Grafik und Sound[/h1]

Die Grafik ist sehr gut gelungen, die Menschen sind echt nur der Hintergrund ist so animiert das alles sehr gut zusammen passt.
Der Sound ist auch sehr gut jede Attacke hat einen eigenen Sound.

[h1]Postiv[/h1]

-Passende Grafik
-Guter Sound
-Viele Maps
-Viele Kämpfer
-Guter Preis

[h1]Negativ[/h1]

-Ein paar Bugs

[h1]Wertung[/h1]

[b]Spielspaß 95/100[/b]
Am Anfang ist das Spiel sehr schwierig aber wenn man eine Stunde gespielt hat bringt das Spiel einem sehr viel Spaß.

[b]Grafik 90/100[/b]
Die Grafik ist sehr gut, die Menschen sind echt nur der Hintergrund wurde animiert und es passt sehr gut zusammen.

[b]Sound 80/100[/b]
Der Sound ist sehr gut, jede Attacke hat einen eigenen Sound.

[b]Technik 85/100[/b]
Der Aufbau des Spiels ist immer gleich erst kommt ein Text in dem steht wo der Kampf ist dann kämpfst du und wenn du gewonnen hast kommt das gleiche nochmal.
Das Spiel hat ein paar Bugs aber ist noch nie abgestürzt.

[b]Maps 75/100[/b]
Die Maps sind immer 2D mit mehreren Stufen. Der Standort des Spiels ist in Paris und es gibt auch sehr viele Maps aber irgendwann hat man auf jeder Map mal gespielt und dann wird es Langweilig.

[h1]Gesamt 80/100[/h1]

[h1]Fazit[/h1]

Ein sehr gutes und lustiges Kampf-Spiel das jedem Spaß bringen wird.

21550689.review:
A solid, surprisingly deep beat-em-up. Battles are in 2D, but take place on multiple "planes" that you can jump between at will, much like Guardian Heroes. Combat is heavily based on a wide variety of devastating "Fury" moves like upheaving bursts of fire, powerful area-of-effect clearing blasts, and excessive punch combos. 

The most notable point is that despite the gameplay, the game's graphics and art direction are hilarious: it's a hilarious parody of games like Pit Fighter and early Mortal Kombat, but seemingly much more self-aware and in on the joke, which works well with the game's atmosphere. It works extremely well as a "parody" of the genre, but doesn't skimp on the gameplay as a result, as the battles are a bit more involved than the average beat-em-up, what with the wide variety of moves.

The only real issue is the lack of online co-op. Aside from that, if you're a fan of beat-em-ups and the early 90's digitized photo graphics aesthetic, and like beat-em-ups that aren't just button mashing, don't hesitate to pick this up.

21151331.review:
[url=http://www.le-serpent-retrogamer.org/street-of-fury-ex-mortal-kombat-x-street-of-rage/]> Retrouvez cette critique en images sur le Serpent Retrogamer <[/url]

[b]Dans le début des années 1990, un nouvel artifice graphique dans les jeux vidéo est perçue comme le summum du réalisme : les images digitalisées. Le principe est de prendre des vidéos de vrais acteurs et de les numériser pour en faire des sprites. L’exemple le plus connu reste le jeu Mortal Kombat et ses fatality. Mais malgré d’autres exemples de jeux, la mode s’estompe assez vite tandis que la 3D fait son entrée, pour revenir 20 ans plus tard. Les développeurs Français de Guard Crush Games décident de rendre hommage à leur façon avec une beat them all, non pas en 8 bit ni en 3D mais avec des acteurs. Le résultat s’appelle Street Of Fury EX, reste à savoir si cette originalité fait un jeu.[/b]

[h1]PARIS BRÛLE T-IL?[/h1]

Dans cette reprise de Street Of Rage, le scénario tient sur une demi feuille de papier. La ville de Paris est complètement submergée par les gang dans une version catastrophique des émeutes de 2005, et même l’armée est en grève. L’Etat Français fait appel à vous, membre des grang de L.A pour faire le nettoyage et rétablir la sécurité. Vous allez donc dans le mode campagne affronter les caïd un à un , chacun ayant ses propres coups spéciaux et son armée de sbires prêts à se battre jusqu’à la mort. Pendant la sélection des personnages, on sent le bon cliché de la rue : des messieurs à capuches, des flingues, des wesh ma gueule ou encore des karatékas (?). Le fait que tous ont été digitalisés a partir de l’équipe de développement rend le résultat plutôt mythique. Un guest vient d’ailleurs s’incruster dans la bataille, bien connu des habitués de youtube : Benzaie.  Mais passons au jeu en lui même, et aux techniques de combat de nos guerriers des rues. Pour vaincre les ennemis, le joueur possède trois coups : un coup classique qui fait peu de dégâts et deux coups puissants plus utiles. Ces deux derniers utilisent cependant de l’endurance et il faudra récupérer entre deux séries de mandales. Enfin une barre de fury se remplit tout au long des combats, permettant de lancer des coups spéciaux à la manière d’un Street Of Rage. L’avantage de Street OF Fury EX est de proposer des variantes des coups cités ci-dessus que ce soit par l’ajout d’une direction, par une fury associé à chaque bouton ou des combos. Ajoutez à cela des conbos, et vous obtenez un jeu avec un gameplay digne d’un jeu de combat de la période Street Fighter 2. Et c’est bien là sa seule qualité, car pour être honnête : on s’ennuie.

[h1]UN DÉLIRE DE DÉVELOPPEURS NE FAIT PAS UN BON JEU[/h1]

En mettant de côté le parti pris graphique des images digitalisées, qui ne plaira pas à tout le monde mais qui est assumé, le jeu ressemble plus à un trip sous acide des développeurs mis tel quel en mouvement. Les environnements sont tout d’abord très peu inspirés, et on alternera entre ville/métro/ville/métro, avec seulement quelques plans modifiés. Je ne dis pas que Paris est une ville multicolore, mais là c’est déprimant, et le level design n’arrange pas les choses. Pas de phases en scrolling forcé, d’intérieurs (sauf le métro), pas de plateformes (Double Dragon), ici on avance et on tape, en espérant ne pas brûler ses précieux crédits. Il y a bien trois niveaux de profondeur pour varier les plaisirs mais on touche au principal problème de EX : son côté répétitif. J’avais fait à peu près la même remarque pour Hyrule Warriors, à savoir foncer dans des ennemis à l’IA très variable en enchaînant coups-attaque spéciale-coups-…, avant de passer à la suite. On peut essayer tous les personnages disponibles, et débloquer les autres pour voir leur set de mouvements, mais si le reste ne suit pas on en revient à toujours prendre le même membre de gang. On essaye alors les autres modes comme les “Challenges” ou le “Survival” mais ce ne sont que des variantes basés sur le même jeu de base, donc vite lassantes. Bon point néanmoins, le multijoueur jusqu’à 4 peut permettre dans une soirée arrosé de délirer entre potes une fois ou deux. Pour résumer une bonne déception.

[h1]A retenir[/h1]

[b]Street Of Fury EX partait du principe qu’il fallait faire du second degré (scénario, graphisemes) mais oublie de nombreuses choses dans le jeu final. Malgré un gameplay plutôt fourni, le jeu est assez répétitif, plutôt moche et équipe ses ennemis d’une IA assez incompréhensible. Seul le multijoueur rattrape un peu le tout et permet de passer une ou deux soirées sympas avec des bières. A prendre à petit prix ou si vous êtes fan de Benzaie.[/b]

Je change d'avis je recommande tout de même parce que le gameplay est putain jouissif et addictif.

En solde la pillule passe toute seule. A plein tarif ca reste trop cher a mon avis.

Y'a 3 persos et demi pour faire les ennemis et tout ce qui change c'est leur couleur ou taille.
Tout ce qui fait l'interet de ce jeu c'est Benzaie, Bob Lenon (eux on fait vraiment bien leur persos) et la nostalgie. A 10 balles c'est trop cher. Mais bon ca a le mérite d'être drôle.
C'est un bon mauvais jeu. Ca aurait plus de sens si yavait JDG.

Il y a de très bon point et notemment que franchement c'est très drole. C'est un joyeux bordel.
L'animation est fluide et la mechanique de combos est franchement sympa.
Si vous avez envie de rire et que les beat em all oldschool vous manque....

20148023.review:
Great game. You can't just button mash. You have to figure out how to approach some enemies, and they all have different abilities, so you can't just keep rushing in and trying to start your standard combo.

Combos are fun to pull off, and fairly satisfying.

The visual style is unique and ridiculous (as you can see from the screenshots and video, it's normal-looking people mo-capped), perfectly fitting for what it is. Because it's so blatantly ridiculous, I think it's funny.

The story is also ridiculous just like every other side-scrolling beat-em-up. Don't worry about it.

Music and sound, also great and perfectly fitting for the thing. I think the hit sounds having a bit more oomph would make combos feel a bit more satisfying, but it's alright as it is now.

I was hoping to see some bboys because the French are known for bboying, but I didn't see anything like that. Maybe in a future update or something lol.

All in all a great game. Worth the full price especially to support the devs because this is mad fun, and a must-have if you like clever beat-em-ups.

都没有看到中文评测，我来简单说一下试玩感受吧！
这个游戏我当时一看到介绍视频，就想起了国人制作的《东东不死传说》。和东东不同的是，这款游戏是横版过关游戏，给我一种新的体验。
里面可选的角色还是很多的，随着等级的提升，可以解锁非常多可用的角色，每个角色都很有特点。有的比较正常，有的……丧心病狂（各个方面都丧心病狂……）
所有的角色都是真人，我个人还是很喜欢这种设定的。相比“东东”来说，这款游戏的人物要丰满了许多，各种细节刻画的很出色，所以对于画面没有很大期待的我来说，算是一个惊喜吧！
最后是重点了，那就是打击感和连续技啦！本作的打击感还是可以的，连续技配合非常多，只要可以摸到对手的身体，什么招式都可以连！各种浮空，各种追加，非常爽！每个角色还有三种超杀，空中也可以放超杀~不过也不是逆天，因为加入了保护设定，被浮空一定程度之后，会强行落地（保护），这样不至于一套把人连死，还是比较平衡的。
战斗中，会显示连击数，连击结束之后，会显示这次连击的总伤害值，可以明确的知道自己这套连击造成的伤害。
唯一不爽的……居然没有翻滚…只有一个后跳…被两面包夹的时候很不爽！！！！
最后推荐大家买买买，如果喜欢横版过关和格斗的话，不要犹豫了，很好玩！！

Une excellente surprise!

Une reprise maitrisée des codes des Beat'em all de l'époque, réaffinés avec un tas de subtilités modernes et originales.

Ne vous laissez pas méprendre par le rendu photo, qui laisserai penser qu'il s'agit d'un simple jeu "kitch", ce jeu est une mine de techniques et combos à découvrir et à optimiser.

On sent l'influence de jeux comme Guardian Heroes de Treasure, ou la série des Real Bout Fatal Fury de SNK, mais aussi un tas d'autres grands noms du genre Beat'em all/Versus Fighing.

Le jeu est jouable jusqu'à 4 en même temps, avec un mode solo en coop à l'ancienne, et un mode versus à 4 totalement jubilatoire!

Sans compter que le jeu est régulièrement mis à jour avec l'ajout de persos totalement gratuitement ;)

Bref, je vous le recommande les yeux fermés :)

Действие происходит во Франции, где вы играете за задротов или просто странных смешных людей, есть уличные танцоры, дылды, просто психи и очкарики металлисты, у каждого свои приемы и движения. 18215019.review:
This game is a parody of old school beat-em-up games. A really good parody!

Seriously, on my first playthrough I couldn't stop smiling or laughing even when i tried. If you played this kind of games in the 90s you'll know what I'm talking about when you play this one :P

Anyway, the fighting mechanics are solid; in fact they are better than most old beat-em-ups. There are a lot of  playable/unlockable characters with unique personalities and fighting styles. And, for the most part, their animations are very smooth. The gameplay can be a bit repetitive, but very polished and challenging.

I wish they included more female characters and female enemy npcs. In fact, I wish they had a bigger variety of unique enemies as a whole, especially when it comes to the bosses. Still, by combining different enemy types on each level the game will push you to keep coming up with new strategies.

The one thing that failed to impress me is the level design. Levels are kind repetitive and flat. In the old-school fighting games you were fighting on moving trains, inside buildings, inside elevators, on beaches, in gardens, etc. There were bystanders, destructible barrels and boxes, power-ups and weapons that you could pick up. Not here unfortunately. Most of the time in Streets of Fury you are fighting either in the streets, parking garages, or the subway platform, but the textures and colors are so similar for each location that it feels like you are on the same stage over and over.

Despite the shortcomings, Streets of Fury EX is a great game. Well worth the $10 price. I really want a sequel. (But please improve level design!)

17606506.review:
Short review:

http://images.akamai.steamusercontent.com/ugc/431571327798766106/93745073670DC86C31A3BED192BD073E62DD89D8/

I just did a 1191 hit combo with a skinny French boxer. What other game allows you to do that?

---------------------------------

Long review:

This game plays very, very nice. The graphics may look like doodoo, but when the gameplay is so excellent, it really doesn't matter. It's kind of charming in its own way.

Mechanics:
Your characters have a lot of attacks and you can do all sorts of crazy juggle combos; just watch the trailer to see the kind of extreme techniques that you have at your disposal. You'll never feel limited and you'll keep wanting to discover more and more combos.

Controls: 
Sharp, on point. This is very important in a beat em up. Button layout is easy to comprehend.

Music:
Very catchy music! It resembles 90s techno, which is the perfect tribute to a classic beat em up.

Extras:
Co-op is couch 4 player and players can jump in. There are two campaigns and while they share similar areas, you recruit CPU allies in the second one to help out. There is also Challenge, Survival and Versus. The game can be very challenging on Normal, don't be ashamed to play on Easy or ask a friend to join you.


Conclusion:

Just buy the game, it's way too much fun! A wonderful tribute to old beat em ups and lots of nods to 2D fighting games. There's even Jesse from Breaking Bad as a playable character! At 10 bucks, it's a steal. You'll get plenty of your money's worth.

17014283.review:
As a fan of side-scrolling beat-em-ups, I was a massive advocate of the original SoF on XBLIG and got loads of my friends into it. So you can imagine my delight on discovering that this game wasn't going to die as an unknown cult classic and that they were doing an updated version for PC.

IMHO, this is the best "Go Straight" beat-em-up after Streets of Rage Remake, but that has the advantage of already having a template, music, sprites, etc to work from. Streets of Fury, however, has a far better combo system! Seriously, the amount of variety and personalisation of the combos is a joy. It's also taken a leaf or two from the Saturn/XBLA classic Guardian Heroes, which is probably the other member of the "Best Scrolling Beat-em-ups Trilogy".

Yeah, the graphics can look a bit dodgy a first glance - but look at the animation! The more you look at and play with the characters, the work more you see has gone into making some excellent game mechanics. The music's great, there's loads of interesting and diverse characters, 4-player co-op/versus, unlockables, a couple of fun modes, etc and from what I hear, there's more content in the pipeline... This won't convert people who hate the genre, but there's definitely something quite pure and essentially videogamey about a game like this that a lot of people will enjoy - definitely recommended.

16839175.review:
Streets of Fury was the best beatemup on the Xbox Live Indie Games Service.
...
Wow. That's not saying anything at all.
Ok.
Streets of Fury EX is one of the best beatemups on Steam.
Eh? Eh?!
What? That's still not saying anything? Jeeze.

Beatemups are a tough genre to figure out. When you break it down enough, it's just walking up to people and punching them in the face. However, there's much more to it than that. This is a genre that demands perfect mechanics, solid controls, and the right balance of challenge, depth, and entertainment. Most developers don't even get the mechanics right, let alone everything else. 

Streets of Fury EX gets practically everything right. On first glance it looks ridiculous, but that's part of its charm. Not everyone is going to be nostalgic of games starring digitized characters, but I don't know. I kinda hope they'll make a come-back. It also helps that the cast of characters are uh...mostly normal. It reminds me of Dong Dong Never Die. That was a game filled with random people that can somehow throw fireballs, soar through the air, and cause earthquakes when they stomp the ground. 

There are 15+ playable heroes in SoFEX. Each fighter has a set of regular moves, special attacks, and a handful of supers. Combining these techniques to create combos is extremely enjoyable. Even during the beatemup genre's peak (the 90s) most combos were just mashing the attack button to perform automatic moves. With this game, if it keeps the enemy in the air, it counts. This game uses a lot of ideas present in other fighters, such as ground bounces, launchers, and OTG shenanigans. Basically, this means that you have a lot of tools to play around with. While unnecessary, it's also nice that each character has a distinct personality. Most of them have multiple taunts as well as unique "death" animations.

While it would probably be enough to create a bunch of dullard enemies to style on, SoFEX relies on making every enemy unique. There are a ton of re-used sprites (as per genre-standards), but they all have different strategies. Let's look at the Jesse Pinkman knock-offs. These jerks use guns. The orange Jay Cees don't attack, but will shoot you out of the air. Red? He taunts and then fires, which has the added affect of making him partially invulnerable (unless guard-broken). As for green, he just fires with no warning, but has no invincibility. No Jessy can be approached in the same manner. This ideal extends to the entirety of the enemy roster. 

The two campaigns do a fine job of exploring the possible enemy combinations. Eventually you'll grasp what works, and try to maximize your damage in the few openings you can create. It's the perfect showcase for the real depth that can be found in a beatemup. In order to beat someone down, you have to work for it. This aspect is further driven into the player's head in the Survival mode. In each wave, the player must contend with increasing odds. The enemies are randomized, which can result in an numerous combinations. It's up to the player to use the myriad of tools at their disposal to separate foes from the pack and give them a quick yet thorough crushing. The bad-guys will not shy away from making the player suffer. In later waves, a single screw-up can lead to the player getting juggled for half their health. 

For another kind of challenge, the...uh..challenge mode offers numerous battles. It's almost like a puzzle game. You have to figure out the right character, what enemies to focus on, and which moves to perform. There are a few "kick everyone's ass" missions, but most of the time you're going to try different combinations and ideas until you find the one that really works. It's a satisfying addition. An amusing bonus that shouldn't be ignored is the campaign edit. Various parameters can be changed, from enemy aggressiveness & numbers to gravity to how fast everyone moves. This can result in tons of hilarity, as well as even more ways to play through the game. 

More important than anything else: This is a beatemup that just [i]feels[/i] right. The mechanics are properly handled. There is enough satisfaction when punching an enemy, as well as appropriate warning when an enemy is going to attack. This is accomplished through animations and flashing effects. If you have a watchful eye and keep your ears open, you'll always have an idea of what's going on, even when 10+ enemies are on-screen. Every hit is on-point, nothing feels cheap or leaves you thinking "how'd he hit me?! He was way over there!" Within minutes of playing you get a feel for how everything works, and can start working on the finer details as well as developing your own amazing combos. 

This game is missing online-play...which hurts bad. The last release didn't have it either but damn, I hope it happens eventually. Couch co-op is always an option at least. In any case, this game will last quite awhile. I couldn't tell you where Streets of Fury EX stands among the classics, but it is one of the finest beatemups released in the 21st century.

I hope that's saying something.

[i]If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Original_Curators_Group#curation]Follow Original Curator Group[/url][/i]

16786673.review:
Pure, stupid fun.  That's Streets of Fury EX in a nutshell.  It reminds me of the sort of game a bunch of my buddies in high school and I might have made, had digital cameras and cheap chromakey software been widely available then.  But underneath the somewhat amateurish look is a surprisingly deep and fun side-scrolling beat 'em up, with tight controls and a robust combo system.  Stringing together multi-hit beatdowns is a snap, and each of the many unlockable characters has a full arsenal of combat moves, including chargable super attacks.  Up to four players can join in local co-op, and survival and challenge modes are also available.  Sadly, there's no online play, nor is there a training mode to practice your combos.       

If the game seems familiar, that's because it originally made its debut in 2007 on the Xbox Indie Games service, and was a finalist in the the 2008 Dream Build Play competition.  The 360 version was fun, but clearly constrained by limitations of the hardware and the platform.  The smooth animation of the video-captured sprites meant that only a few actors were used, and their footage spread across multiple characters with extremely similar movesets.  In a genre that's already heavy on repitition, that's not a good thing.  But for the remaster, the developers added a slew of new, distinct brawlers, many of whom parody popular fighting game icons (check out the martial artist with his Ryu-style Shin Shoryuken, or the scarf-wearing send-up of Street Fighter 3's Q).  Guard Crush Games even apparently got one of their dads to play the end boss!  The fighting system has also been revised, with some control changes and a "stamina" meter added, which can be used for powerful special moves or to block enemy attacks.  

Overall, this is definitely worth a look even if you played the original eight years ago (yikes, has it really been that long?).

16748601.review:
I sunk a huge amount of time into the original Xbox 360 version of the game, and Streets of Fury is one of my favourite indie games from last gen. I was pretty amped to discover that they were planning on doing a PC version of this, so I've been patiently waiting...

Streets of Fury is a throwback to late 80's - early 90's arcade style beat-em ups done in the style of games like old-skool Mortal Kombat using digitized sprites. Streets of Fury sports a very competent and deep combo system that is simple and pick-up-and-playable for beginners, while more experienced players can string together ridiculously long combos that look like something out of a high level MvC2 or Skullgirls match...

The EX version takes everything from the original and simply expands & improves on it.

[b]+[/b] Larger roster of playable characters.
[b]+[/b] New enemy types. And unique sprites for all of them :D
[b]+[/b] New game modes.
[b]+[/b] Higher res sprites, and improved environment visuals/variety.
[b]+[/b] Gameplay tweaks & streamlined control scheme.
[b]+[/b] Some new music as well.


[h1]Some notable changes from the original:[/h1]
+ With the dash and lane switching tied to the direction keys, it means you can play this game with a keyboard & fight stick perfectly fine. In the original, you were required to use the triggers to dash, and switch lanes...

+ The stamina meter, is a simple addition to the game but changes the way you'll need to approach this game if you're coming from the original version. Basically, whenever you use a special attack it requires some stamina and if you run out then you won't be able to do any special attacks until it fills up a bit... R.I.P gun-cancel infinite spam :(
Where things get complicated is that your stamina meter also doubles as your guard/armor meter so blocking attacks reduces your stamina and losing all your stamina causes you to guard break. It should be noted that both players and enemies use stamina.


And while I do like this game, there are some glaring omissions, and just some general stuff I don't like with this version.

[h1]Stuff missing:[/h1]
- Character movelists from the original. Seriously why was this not included???
- Combo tutorial videos. I found these very useful, and having these videos in the original gave players an easy way to see what the general playstyle of the characters were, as well as a basis for building combos.

[h1]General annoyances:[/h1]
- 2015, and still no online play for both the co-op and versus :(
- The button prompts in this game do not reflect your current control scheme and prompt simply assume that you're playing this game with an Xbox 360 pad using the default key binds.
- Characters are locked behind a level gate again, sigh... The variety of characters, and mastery of the characters already give you enough incentive to replay this game IMO, so this is just pointless grinding...
- This is just a personal nitpick, but I really did not like the inclusion of the enemy that swears all the time. It was something that really stuck out like a sore thumb for me, and IMO doesn't gel with the silly, playful nature of this game. Fortunately they included a language-filter option for that guy lol.


[h1]Overall Rating:[/h1]
- If you're looking for an old-skool arcade brawler with some fighting game sensibilities then I recommend it on account that you're perfectly okay with playing this solo & local co-op/versus.

16702942.review:
Vous prennez un gameplay à la Guardian Heroes avec un environnement urbain et pas mal de référence à Street Of Rage et un come back dans les années 90s avec des personnage digitalisé, mais pas de stop motion, non ma bonne dame, ce sont de vrai petit bout de vidéo ce qui rend le tout bien plus fluide qu'un Mortal Kombat classique (ou tout autre jeu du meme genre mais plus dans le genre de ce jeu avec des déesses grecques en bikini).

Ce jeu est cool, un peu cheap dans sa direction artistique mais c'est aussi pleinement assumé, bien entendu seul c'est vraiment pas marrant du tout mais à deux joueurs et plus c'est vraiment un pur bonheur dans l'art pugilistique, question pugilat justement, les combos sont super agreable à sortir et à voir, on trouve aussi un mode versus si vous voulez en decoudre avec vos amis, et là c'est beaucoup comme le mode versus de Guardian Heroes (ou le versus fighting de Bleach et Yuyu Hakusho fait justement par Treasure).

Mais si le jeu fera le buzz ça sera en partie par la presence d'un invité de marque en la presence de Benjamin Daniel et son alter ego mono testiculaire du Hard Corner.

Un bon défouloir et un bon acha si vous etes nostalgique des beat'em up année 90 et de sa fievre de la digitalisation.

16700820.review:
Full video review here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N5LQVtGX8Ho

France is in turmoil and it’s time to call a couple of bad dudes to handle the situation. Choose from a list of regular looking people wearing rugged clothing and fight your way to the Big Boss. That’s really the story, I mean it is a beat-em up title after all!

High Points

Beat them down – Streets of Fury EX excels at the classic go straight formula. You can select from a wide variety of characters and proceed down the street beating the living crap out of anyone in your way. There is a direction based combo system in place that allows you to air juggle opponents, guard crush, or pull off powerful special abilities.

Mortal Kombat with a hint of Narc – Visually it hits the nostalgia factor with the live action combat of a Mortal Kombat title. The backgrounds remind me a bit of the old Narc arcade title. The game has that pasted together look that most live-action based Arcade games usually have. It works well for a game that is clearly intended for the coin-op generation.
 
Cooperative play – Playing with a friend is the absolute way to play Streets of Fury EX. The combat is less cheap with two people watching each other’s backs and stringing together combo after combo. I was only able to play this with two players, but I can only imagine the insanity of playing with four others!

Nitpicks

No Online Play – Local only cooperative play in a world of the internet. Hope you have four controllers and a few friends that want to come over and play a ragtag arcade game. 

Lack of enemy variety – By the time you’ve reached the third act of the story, you’ve fought everyone in the game. They will then distinguish themselves by walking around with disco lighting all over their bodies or adding a different animation to their attacks. It starts to become repetitive for what is mostly a game you can plow through in about forty-five minutes.  

Low Points

Queued up moves – There isn’t a lot of room for reaction to certain moves in the game. Unlike beat-em ups in the Arcades of the 90’s, there is a lack of fluidity when attempting to fight multiple enemies. Let’s use Streets of Rage 2 as example. I can easily fight a character in front of me, spin around and attack the next one and move in-between the foreground and background to avoid attacks. 

Streets of Fury EX queues up moves and leaves you vulnerable to attacks. Unlike most games that allow you to spin around and immediately attack, the only type of defense in these instances is to block and wait for a counter-attack. It leads to a lot of unfair ass beatings while playing solo, which means this game was truly intended for cooperative audiences. 

Terrible character choices - There are a lot of brawlers to play as, but a large amount of them are dreadful. Despite the awful choices in clothing some of them wear, there are just too many that leave themselves open to attacks. Not a lot of attention was paid to making these fighters functional combatants. At least sixty percent of these fighters are straight up doo-doo on a cheese sandwich and that’s the opposite of delicious. 

Conclusion

Streets of Fury EX is an Arcade game from the 90’s in the year 2015. It’s only going to appeal to people with that hint of nostalgia in their hearts. It’s not anywhere near a masterpiece but it does provide us with a fair amount of coop beat-em up action. I’ll be honest… you probably won’t want to shell full price out for this. It’s a bit rough around the edges in terms of beat-em ups, and fails to live up to the genre with a barebones combat scheme.

16699608.review: I put countless hours into the 360 version of this when it was release for the Indie Game service quite a few years back.  I just built my gaming PC and figured this game was already available.  Well I certainly was excited to see the game being re-released with more characters and new enemies.  If you like beat em ups and deep combo systems, there's no possible way you couldn't like this game.  It has so much combo potential and each character plays different enough to want to try them all out and create some cool combos.  If you like Streets of Rage, Final Fight, Guardian Heroes, etc there's no reason you shouldn't pick this up.
